conclusion: Objects A and B are released and move through the air due to gravity, coming into contact with objects C, D, E, and F.
As soon as A and B are released, they accelerate downwards under gravity.
Object A is positioned above blocks C and D, and object B is positioned above blocks E and F.
The first solid surfaces A and B meet are the upper faces of blocks C–D (for A) and E–F (for B).
Each falling object loses its downward velocity through an inelastic contact with the corresponding pair of blocks.
The normal force from the block material balances the weight of A and B.
With no further unbalanced forces, both A and B come to rest on top of the blocks or very close to them depending on the exact geometry.
Nothing topples or slides provided the blocks are sufficiently massive and the contacting surfaces have ordinary friction.
A settles on the upper surface shared by C and D, and B settles on the surface shared by E and F, remaining there in static equilibrium.
